analytic.title: Systems & Control Letters

biblStruct.note: Received 17 November 2011 Received in revised form 10 June 2012 Accepted 15 October 2012

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Multi-agent system Finite-time tracking Dynamic output feedback Containment control Formation control

div.p: This paper addresses the distributed finite-time tracking control problem for second-order multi-agent systems. First, we propose a finite-time tracking protocol for multi-agent systems by using state feedback. Then, a new class of observer-based control algorithms are designed for achieving finite-time consensus tracking in multi-agent systems with a single active leader, where each agent can only share its position states with its neighbors. Within the same context, the present control algorithms are then extended to solve the finite-time containment tracking problem for multi-agent systems in the presence of multiple active leaders. It is theoretically shown that the position states of the followers will converge to that of the leader or a convex hull spanned by those of the leaders, respectively, in finite time. Furthermore, the finite-time formation control problem is discussed. The effectiveness of the results is also illustrated by numerical simulations.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Over the past few years, distributed control of multi-agent systems has attracted much attention from various scientific communities, due to its higher robustness, less communication cost, greater efficiency, and so on [1]. One interesting and important issue arising from distributed control of multi-agent systems is to design distributed protocols based only on the local relative information to guarantee the states of all agents to reach an agreement, known as the consensus problem.

Motivated by the pioneering work of [2,3], a general framework of the consensus problem for first-order multi-agent systems was suggested and studied in [4]. The consensus conditions derived in [4] were further relaxed in [5]. It was shown that consensus of first-order multi-agent systems can be achieved if and only if the time-varying network topology contains a directed spanning tree frequently enough as the network evolves. Recently, the consensus problem for second-order multi-agent systems has received increasing attention, partly due to its wide potential applications. Motivated by this observation, a class of second-order multi-agent system models were introduced and analyzed in [6], where some sufficient conditions were obtained for achieving consensus asymptotically. By using tools from eigenvalue analysis and bifurcation theory, some necessary and sufficient conditions for second-order consensus in directed networks containing a directed spanning tree were derived in [7]. The above-mentioned literature mainly focuses on consensus for a group of agents without any leader. However, in some practical applications, there might exist one or even multiple leaders in the networks. It is thus important to study consensus tracking problem in multiagent systems. In [8], a distributed neighbor-based estimator was designed to solve consensus tracking problem for multi-agent systems with an active leader. In [9], a distributed coordinated tracking problem for multiple Euler-Lagrange systems with a dynamic leader was investigated. Furthermore, several novel distributed tracking controllers were designed in [10] for multiagent systems with general linear node dynamics.

Convergence rate, as a significant performance index to evaluate the effectiveness of the control algorithms in the study of consensus tracking problem, is a hot research topic in the area of consensus problem. To obtain faster convergence rate, various consensus protocols with larger coupling strength, better communication topology and the optimal gain were designed and analyzed [11][12][13][14][15]. However, it can be observed that most of the above-mentioned consensus algorithms can only guarantee the states of agents to converge to agreement asymptotically. In practical applications, it may be desirable to achieve consensus tracking in finite time. Therefore, it is meaningful to investigate the finite-time consensus tracking problem in network systems. Compared with asymptotic control for the consensus problem of multi-agent systems, finite-time control is an effective approach to construct effective protocols with high performance such as a faster convergence rate. Besides, systems under finite-time controller usually demonstrate better robustness to uncertainty and disturbance rejection. In [16], some continuous state feedback control laws were developed to solve finite-time synchronization problem of chaotic systems. In [17], a finite-time consensus algorithm for discrete-time systems was studied by using the property of minimal polynomial of weight matrix. In [18], the finite-time state consensus problem under switching topology for continuous-time multi-agent systems was investigated by using a continuous protocol. Finite-time consensus problems for secondorder dynamics were also addressed by many researchers. For example, some necessary and sufficient conditions for finitetime semi-stability of homogeneous multi-agent systems were addressed in [19]. In [20], a simple but efficient framework was proposed to achieve finite-time decentralized formation tracking of multi-agent systems by using a decentralized sliding mode estimators.

Motivated by the above-mentioned results, this paper discusses the finite-time tracking problem of second-order multi-agent systems by using an observer-based approach. We first propose a class of finite-time tracking protocols based on the relative state information. Then, a framework for constructing a finite-time tracking protocol based only on the relative output measurements of neighboring agents is developed. It is shown that the separation principle of traditional observer-based controllers still holds in finite-time control for multi-agent systems. In contrast to the previous works related to finite-time tracking by using static state feedback, the present protocols rely only on the relative position measurements, which can be regarded as an extension of the traditional observer-based controller of a single system to the one for multi-agent systems. By using tools from homogeneous theory, it is theoretically proved that finite-time consensus tracking can be achieved for multi-agent systems with a single leader, if the topology is connected and at least one follower can obtain the position states of the leader. Furthermore, the finite-time containment control problem for multi-agent systems in the presence of multiple leaders is addressed. It is theoretically shown that the states of the followers will reach the convex hull formed by those of the leaders in finite time, if for each follower there exists at least one leader that has a directed path to that follower. Finally, an application to finite-time formation control is provided to extend the main results.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Notations and some basic preliminaries are presented in Section 2. Main theoretical results are provided in Section 3. Finally, Section 4 concludes the paper.

div.head: Notations and preliminaries
div.p: Notations: Let R n×n and C n×n be the sets of n × n real and complex matrices, respectively, and I N be the identity matrix. P > 0 (P < 0) means that the matrix P is positive (negative) definite.
1 represents the vector with all entries being one. The Kronecker product of matrices A ∈ R m×n and B ∈ R p×q is defined as
Lemma 1 ([21]). Given matrices A, B, C and D with compatible dimensions, we have the following results:

div.head: Graph theory
div.p: A directed graph G = (V, E ) consists of a set of nodes V = {1, 2, . . . , N} and a set of edges E ⊂ V × V, which is a set of directed pairs of nodes. A directed edge (i, j) ∈ E in graph G means that node j can obtain information from node i, but not conversely.
The neighbors of node i are denoted as
div.formula: N i = {j ∈ V | (j, i) ∈ E }.
div.p: An undirected graph G = (V, E ) also consists of a set of nodes V = {1, 2, . . . , N} and a set of edges E ⊂ V × V, which is a set of undirected pairs of nodes. An undirected edge (i, j) ∈ E in graph G means that two nodes i, j are adjacent or neighboring. A directed path from node i 1 to node i s on directed graph G is a sequence of ordered directed edges with the form (i k , i k+1 ), k = 1, . . . , s -1.
An undirected path between node i 1 and node i s on undirected graph means a sequence of ordered undirected edges with the form
A graph G is said to be connected if there exists a path between each pair of distinct nodes.

div.head: The adjacency matrix of graph G is denoted by
div.formula: A = (a ij ) ∈ R N×N , where a ij = 1 if (j, i) ∈ E , a ij = 0 otherwise. The Laplacian matrix of the graph associated with adjacency matrix A is given as L = (l ij ), where l ii =  N j=1 a ij and l ij = -a ij , i ̸ = j.
div.p: Clearly, matrices L and A are symmetric if the graph is undirected.

Throughout this paper, the communication topology verifies the following two assumptions: Assumption 1. The communication topology between the followers is undirected. Assumption 2. For each follower, there exists at least one leader that has a directed path to it.

The major objective of this paper is to design a distributed control law based on relative output measurements of neighboring agents to guarantee that the states of the followers to track that of the leader or a convex hull spanned by those of the multiple leaders in finite time.

div.head: Some basic results of finite-time control
div.p: In this subsection, some basic results of finite-time control theory are provided.
div.formula: Definition 1. Given a vector x = (x 1 , . . . , x n ) T , define |x| α = (|x 1 | α , . . . , |x n | α ) T , sig(x) α = (sgn(x 1 )|x 1 | α , . . . , sgn(x n )|x n | α ) T ,(1)
div.p: where α ∈ R.
Lemma 2 ([22,23]). Consider the following dynamical system
div.formula: ẋ1 = x 2 , ẋ2 = -M(l 1 sig(x 1 ) α 1 + l 2 sig(x 2 ) α 2 ),(2)
where x 1 , x 2 ∈ R n , M is a positive definite matrix. System (2) is globally finite-time stable if l 1 > 0, l 2 > 0, 0 < α 1 < 1, and α 2 = 2α 1 1+α 1 .
div.p: Lemma 3 ([22,23]). Consider the following dynamical system
div.formula: ẋ1 = x 2 , ẋ2 = -M(l 1 sig(x 1 + e 1 ) α 1 + l 2 sig(x 2 + e 2 ) α 2 ), ė1 = e 2 -k 1 sig(e 1 ) σ 1 , ė2 = -k 2 sig(e 1 ) σ 1 ,(3)
where x 1 , x 2 , e 1 , e 2 ∈ R n , M is a positive definite matrix. (3) is glob- ally finite-time stable if l 1 > 0, l 2 > 0, k 1 > 0, k 2 > 0, 1 2 < σ 1 < 1, α 1 = 2σ 1 -1, α 2 = 2σ 1 -1 σ 1
div.p: Remark 1. Note that in [22,23], the finite-time control problem was investigated and analyzed for a second-order integrator system by using a centralized controller. The results derived in the above-mentioned well-done papers are especially helpful to obtain our main results. Different from the results given in [22,23], one contribution of the present work is that the centralized finitetime control approach has been extended and employed to design a distributed finite-time consensus tracking protocol for multi-agent systems.

div.head: Main results
div.p: In this section, the distributed finite-time consensus tracking control for multi-agent systems is considered. Consider a group of second-order integrator agents given by
div.formula: qi = p i , ṗi = u i , i = 1, . . . , N,(4)
div.p: where q i ∈ R n is the position of agent i, and p i ∈ R n is the velocity. The dynamics of the leader, labeled by N + 1, is given by
div.formula: qd N+1 = p d N+1 , ṗd N+1 = 0 (5)
div.p: with an initial position q d N+1 (0) = r and an initial velocity p d N+1 (0) = v, which generates the desired target trajectory. It is assumed that the leader can only be observed by a small fraction of the followers. And, if follower i can obtain the information from the leader, we refer to node i with a i(N+1) = 1 as a pinned node. Denote the Laplacian matrix between the followers as L p and matrix P as P = diag{a 1(N+1) , . . . , a N(N+1) }. The following property can be obtained by using matrix theory.

div.head: Lemma 4 ([24]
div.p: ). Under Assumptions 1 and 2, matrix P has at least one positive entry and the matrix
div.formula: L f = L p + P (6)
div.p: is a positive definite symmetric matrix. Definition 2. The finite-time consensus tracking problem is solved if and only if there exists T > 0, such that, lim t→T (q i -q d N+1 ) = 0, lim t→T (p i -p d N+1 ) = 0, and
div.formula: q i = q d N+1 , p i = p d N+1 , if t > T , i = 1, . . . , N.

div.head: Distributed finite-time consensus tracking of multi-agent systems by using relative state feedback
div.p: First of all, we investigate the finite-time consensus tracking problem with a leader using state feedback for our further study by using output feedback in the next subsection. Consider a multiagent system described by ( 4) and (5). It is first assumed that the relative states between each agent and its neighbors can be used in this subsection. The protocol based on relative state information is proposed as
div.formula: u i = -l 1 sig  N  i=1 a ij (q i -q j ) + a i (N+1) (q i -q d N+1 )  α 1 -l 2 sig  N  i=1 a ij (p i -p j ) + a i (N+1) (p i -p d N+1 )  α 2 , i = 1, . . . , N,(7)
div.p: where l 1 > 0, l 2 > 0 are feedback gains and α 1 , α 2 ∈ R are parameters to be determined.
Theorem 1. Suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. Then the positions and velocities of the followers under protocol (7) will converge to those of the leader in finite time, respectively, if
Proof. By substituting ( 7) into (4), the closed-loop system of the multi-agent system is transformed into
div.formula: qi = p i , ṗi = -l 1 sig  N  i=1 a ij (q i -q j ) + a i (N+1) (q i -q d N+1 )  α 1 -l 2 sig  N  i=1 a ij (p i -p j ) + a i (N+1) (p i -p d N+1 )  α 2 ,(9)
div.p: where i = 1, . . . , N. Denote q = (q T 1 , . . . , q T N ) T , p = (p T 1 , . . . , p T N ) T , q l = ((q d N+1 ) T , . . . , (q d N+1 ) T ) T and p l = ((p d N+1 ) T , . . . , (p d N+1 ) T ) T . Then, it follows from ( 9) that the closed-loop system of the multi-agent system can be rewritten in matrix form as
div.formula: q = p, ṗ = -l 1 sig[(L p ⊗ I)q + (P ⊗ I)q l ] α 1 -l 2 sig[(L p ⊗ I)p + (P ⊗ I)p l ] α 2 ,
div.p: where L p and P are defined in (6). Let x = qq l and y = pp l , respectively. From ( 5), one has
div.formula: ẋ = y, ẏ = -l 1 sig[(L p ⊗ I)(q -q l ) + (P ⊗ I)(q -q l )] α 1 -l 2 sig[(L p ⊗ I)(p -p l ) + (P ⊗ I)(p -p l )] α 2 , = -l 1 sig[(L f ⊗ I)x] α 1 -l 2 sig[(L f ⊗ I)y] α 2 . Taking linear transformation X = (L f ⊗ I)x and Y = (L f ⊗ I)y, one gets Ẋ = Y , Ẏ = -(L f ⊗ I)(l 1 sig(X ) α 1 + l 2 sig(Y ) α 2 ). (10
div.p: According to Lemma 2 and (8), one obtains that system (10) is globally finite-time stable. Therefore, there exists T > 0, such that lim t→T X = lim t→T Y = 0. By Lemma 4, one has that (L f ⊗ I) is positive definite. Thus, lim t→T x = lim t→T y = 0 since X = (L f ⊗I)x, and Y = (L f ⊗I)y, namely, q and p will converge to q l and p l in finite time, respectively. It implies that the global finite-time consensus tracking control problem of the multi-agent systems (4) and ( 5) is solved by finite-time protocol (7). This complete the proof.

Remark 2. A finite-time protocol based on relative state information is proposed in this subsection. It is assumed that the relative position and velocity information can be obtained. However, this assumption is strict with the case where only the position can be got without velocity measurement. Therefore, a novel observerbased protocol is proposed in the following context based only on the relative position measurement.

div.head: Distributed finite-time consensus tracking of multi-agent systems by using relative output feedback
div.p: In this subsection, the finite-time consensus tracking control for multi-agent systems with a single leader is studied by using relative output information. In what follows, the relative output measurements of other agents with respect to agent i are synthesized into a single signal as
where a ij = 1, if agent i can obtain information from agent j but a ij = 0 otherwise. Based on the above analysis, an observer-based consensus protocol is proposed as
div.formula: δi = η i -k 1 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 1 , ηi =  j∈N i a ij (u i -u j ) -k 2 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 2 , u i = -l 1 sig(δ i ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η i ) α 2 , i = 1, . . . , N,(12)
div.p: where k 1 , k 2 , l 1 , l 2 are feedback gains and σ 1 , σ 2 , α 1 , α 2 ∈ R are parameters to be determined. The term (12) denotes the information exchanges between the protocol of agent i and those of its neighbors. Since the leader acts as a command generator, it is reasonable to assume that the control law u N+1 of the leader is zero, i.e., u N+1 = 0. Note that control protocol (12) is distributed, since it is based only on the relative information of neighboring agents.
div.formula:  j∈N i a ij (u i -u j ) in
div.p: Theorem 2. Suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. Then, the finite-time consensus tracking problem for system (4) with an active leader (5) is solved by protocol (12), if
Proof. Let x i = q i -q d and y i = p i -p d , for i = 1, . . . , N. According to ( 4) and ( 5), one gets
Substituting ( 12) into (14) yields
div.formula: ẋi = y i , ẏi = -l 1 sig(δ i ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η i ) α 2 , δi = η i -k 1 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 1 , ηi = -l 1 N  j=1 l ij sig(δ j ) α 1 -l 2 N  j=1 l ij sig(η j ) α 2 -k 2 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 2 , (15
div.p: where i = 1, . . . , N.
div.formula: Let q = (q T 1 , . . . , q T N ) T , p = (p T 1 , . . . , p T N ) T , z = (z T 1 , . . . , z T N ) T and q d = (1 ⊗ I)q d N+1 .
div.p: Then, according to (11), one has
div.formula: z = (L p ⊗ I)q + (P ⊗ I)(q -q d ) = ((L p + P) ⊗ I)(q -q d ) = (L f ⊗ I)x. (16

) Let x = (x T 1 , . . . , x T N ) T , y = (y T 1 , . . . , y T N ) T , δ = (δ T 1 , . . . , δ T N ) T , η = (η T 1 , . . . , η T N ) T . It follows from (15) that ẋ = y, ẏ = -l 1 sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η) α 2 , δ = η -k 1 sig(δ -z) σ 1 , η = -l 1 (L f ⊗ I)sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 (L f ⊗ I)sig(η) α 2 -k 2 sig(δ -z) σ 2 . (17
div.p: By taking X = (L f ⊗ I)x and Y = (L f ⊗ I)y, one obtains
div.formula: Ẋ = Y , Ẏ = -l 1 (L f ⊗ I)sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 (L f ⊗ I)sig(η) α 2 ,
δ = η -k 1 sig(δ -X ) σ 1 , η = -l 1 (L f ⊗ I)sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 (L f ⊗ I)sig(η) α 2 -k 2 sig(δ -X ) σ 2 . (18
div.p: Let e X = δ -X and e Y = η -Y . One has
div.formula: Ẋ = Y , Ẏ = -(L f ⊗ I)(l 1 sig(X + e X ) α 1 + l 2 sig(Y + e Y ) α 2 ), ėX = e Y -k 1 sig(e X ) σ 1 , ėY = -k 2 sig(e X ) σ 2 . (19
div.p: From Lemma 4, one has that (L f ⊗ I) is positive definite. Then, according to Lemma 3 and ( 13), one gets that system ( 19) is globally finite-time stable. According to the fact that X = (L f ⊗ I)x, Y = (L f ⊗ I)y, it thus follows from Lemma 3 that x = 0, y = 0, which indicates that the states of the followers will converge to that of the leader in finite time. This completes the proof.

Remark 3. Note that the protocol ( 12) is distributed since it relies merely on the relative output measurements between the neighboring agents. Obviously, protocol (12) may also solve the finite-time distributed tracking problem with a stationary leader, i.e., p d N+1 (0) = 0. Also, it is worth noting that Lemma 3 plays an important role in proof of this result.

div.head: Remark 4.
div.p: In contrast to previous works related to finite-time tracking by using static state feedback, protocol ( 12) is designed based only on the relative output measurements. It is also worth mentioning that the separation principle of traditional observerbased controllers for a single system still holds in finite-time consensus tracking problem for multi-agent systems. Moreover, by using protocol (12), the finite-time consensus tracking problem can be transformed into the finite-time stability problem for a single system.

Example 1. Consider multi-agent system (4) with topology as given in Fig. 1. Suppose that there is a active leader in system (4) with q d N+1 (0) = (1, 2, 3) T and p d N+1 (0) = (0.5, 0.5, 0.5) T . In simulations, let

and α 2 = 1/2, one gets that the finite-time consensus tracking problem can be solved by protocol (12) from Theorem 2. The position and velocity states are provided in Figs. 2 and3, from which it can be seen that the followers track the leader at about t = 5.2s. The trajectories of the followers and the leader are given in Fig. 4.

To move on, we study the containment control of multi-agent system with multiple leaders to extend our former results in this framework. Consider the case of multi-agent system with multiple leaders. Suppose that there are N followers and N 1 leaders, where
The communication topology among the N + N 1 agents is denoted by G. An agent is called a leader if the agent has no

neighbor. An agent is called a follower if the agent has at least one neighbor. Without loss of generality, it is assumed that the agents labeled by 1, . . . , N, are followers, while the agents labeled by N + 1, . . . , N + N 1 , leaders whose control inputs are set to be zero. The dynamics of the multiple leaders are given by
div.formula: qd i = p d i , ṗd i = 0,(20)
div.p: with an initial position q d i (0) = r i and an initial velocity
div.formula: p d i (0) = v i , for i = N + 1, . . . , N + N 1 . Denote by L the Laplacian matrix of G.
div.p: Then, L can be partitioned as
where
div.formula: L f ∈ R N×N and L l ∈ R N×N 1 .
div.p: Lemma 5 ([25]). Under Assumptions 1 and 2, one has L f > 0. Moreover, each entry of -L -1
div.formula: f L l is nonnegative and each row sum of -L -1 f L l is equal to one, i.e., -L -1 f L l 1 N 1 = 1 N .
div.p: Definition 3. Consider a multiple leaders network of multi-agent systems described by ( 4) and (20). The distributed containment control problem is said to be solved in finite time if and only if there exists a distributed protocol, based only on the relative states information such that the positions and velocities of the followers converge into the convex hulls co(QL) and co(PL), respectively, by those of the multiple leaders in finite time, where Based only on the relative output information, the control goal here is to guarantee the states of the followers to converge to a convex hull formed by the leaders in finite time. To achieve this goal, the following control protocol is proposed
div.formula: co(QL) = {Σ N+N 1 i=N+1 λ i q i | λ i ≥ 0, Σ N+N 1 i=N+1 λ i = 1}, co(PL) = {Σ N+N 1 i=N+1 λ i p i | λ i ≥ 0, Σ N+N 1 i=N+1 λ i = 1}.

δi = η i -k 1 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 1 , ηi = N  j=1 a ij (u i -u j ) + N+N 1  j=N+1 a ij (u i -u j ) -k 2 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 2 , z i = N+N 1  j=1 a ij (q i -q j ), u i = -l 1 sig(δ i ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η i ) α 2 , i = 1, . . . , N,(22)
div.p: where, k 1 , k 2 , l 1 , l 2 are arbitrarily given positive scalars and σ 1 , σ 2 , α 1 , α 2 ∈ R are parameters to be determined.

Corollary 1. Suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. The the position states of the followers under protocol (22) will converge to the convex hull formed by those of the leaders in finite time if the parameters satisfy (13).
div.formula: Proof. Let q = (q T 1 , . . . , q T N ) T , p = (p T 1 , . . . , p T N ) T , δ = (δ T 1 , . . . , δ T N ) T , η = (η T 1 , . . . , η T N ) T , z = (z T 1 , . . . , z T N ) T , q ml = ((q d N+1 ) T , . . . , (q d N+N 1 ) T ) T , q c = (-L -1 f L l ⊗ I)q ml and u = (u T 1 , . . . , u T N ) T .
div.p: Then, the closed-loop system of ( 4) and ( 22) can be rewritten more compactly as
div.formula: q = p, ṗ = -l 1 sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η) α 2 , δ = η -k 1 sig(δ -z) σ 1 , η = (L f ⊗ I)(-l 1 sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η) α 2 ) -k 2 sig(δ -z) σ 2 . (23
div.p: where z = (L f ⊗I)q+(L l ⊗I)q ml = (L f ⊗I)(q+(L -1 f L l ⊗I)q ml ) = (L f ⊗I)(q-q c ). Let x = q-q c and y = p-p c , where p c is a constant vector. One has
div.formula: ẋ = y, ẏ = -l 1 sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η) α 2 , δ = η -k 1 sig(δ -(L f ⊗ I)x) σ 1 , η = (L f ⊗ I)(-l 1 sig(δ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η) α 2 ) -k 2 sig(δ -(L f ⊗ I)x) σ 2 . (24
div.p: Similar to the analysis in Theorem 2, one has that x and y will converge to zero in finite time, which means that q and p converge to q c and p c in finite time, respectively. According to -L -1
div.formula: f L l 1 N 1 = 1 N . Thus, q c
div.p: ∈ co(QL) and p c ∈ co(PL). This complete the proof. Remark 5. Control protocol (22) is partially motivated by [25], where the containment control of multiple rigid bodies was considered. Compared with control law in [25], the protocol ( 22) is relied only on output information for double-integrator dynamics. Furthermore, the control protocol ( 22) can solve the finite-time containment control problem for systems with multiple leaders, regardless whether they are active or stationary.
Example 2. Consider multi-agent system (4) with three stationary leaders with dynamics (5). The communication topology is given in Fig. 5. Suppose that

one gets that the finite-time containment control problem can be solved by protocol (22) according to Corollary 1. The trajectories of the agents in two-dimensional space are shown in Fig. 6, which indicates that the states of the followers converge to a convex hull formed by those of the leaders at about t = 6s.

div.head: Application to finite-time formation control by using relative output information
div.p: In this subsection, the finite-time control protocol ( 12 Definition 4. The finite-time formation control problem of system (4) is solved if there exists T > 0, such that lim t→T [(q i -h i ) -(q jh j )] = 0, lim t→T (p i -p d N+1 ) = 0, and (q i -h i ) = (q j -h j ), p i = p d N+1 , t > T , for all i, j = 1, 2, . . . , N.
To achieve this goal, the following finite-time formation control protocol is proposed:
div.formula: δi = η i -k 1 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 1 , ηi =  j∈N i a ij (u i -u j ) -k 2 sig(δ i -z i ) σ 2 , z i =  j∈N i a ij [(q i -h i ) -(q j -h j )]
u i = -l 1 sig(δ i ) α 1 -l 2 sig(η i ) α 2 , i = 1, . . . , N.(25)
div.p: Corollary 2. Suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. Then the finitetime formation control problem of system (4) is solved by dynamical output feedback protocol (25).

Example 3. Consider multi-agent system (4) with communication topology as given by Fig. 1. Suppose that there is a active leader (5) in system (4) with q d N+1 (0) = (1, 2, 3) T and p d N+1 (0) = (0.5, 0.5, 0.5) T . In simulations, let h 1 = (0.5, 0, -0.5) T , h 2 = (0.25, 0.6124, -0.25) T , h 3 = (-0.5, 0, 0.5) T , h 4 = (-0.25, 0.6124, 0.25) T , h 5 = (-0.25, -0.6124, 0.25) T , and h 6 = (0.25, -0.6124, -0.25) T . By choosing σ 1 = 2/3, σ 2 = 1/3, α 1 = 1/3, and α 2 = 1/2, one has the distributed control protocol (25) solves the finite-time formation problem from Corollary 2. The simulation result is shown in Figs. 7 and8. The six agents achieve a regular hexagon shape with a separation of √ 2/2 in finite time.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, the distributed finite-time tracking control problem for a class of second-order multi-agent systems under a time-invariant communication topology has been investigated via a observer-based approach. Two new kinds of distributed finitetime protocols based on relative state of output information have been presented and analyzed, respectively. In the case of a single leader, it has been proved the position states of the followers will converge to that of the leader in a finite-time. While, the position of the followers will converge to a convex hull formed by those of the leader in finite time in the case of multiple leaders. Future work will focus on the finite-time consensus of more realistic models, such as multi-agent systems with Euler-Lagrange dynamics, and finite-time consensus under directed topologies.
